thread.title: Where does Rutgers coach Kyle Flood's $1.25M salary rank in Big Ten?
thread.title_full: Where does Rutgers coach Kyle Flood's $1.25M salary rank in Big Ten? | NJ.com

author: Keith Sargeant | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Where does Rutgers coach Kyle Flood's $1.25M salary rank in Big Ten?
text:
This year, Big Ten coaches on average earn more money than their peers in other conferences, according to the USA TODAY's annual study of college football coaching salaries released Thursday.
In 2015, the average salary for the 13 head coaches is $3.21 million, according to the USA TODAY database (as an interim head coach, Illinois' Bill Cubit was omitted from the average).
That average figure swelled this year thanks to the lucrative contract given to Jim Harbaugh, who in his first season as Michigan coach is set to earn at least $7 million annually.
Rutgers coach Kyle Flood, who will serve the final phase of his three-game suspension Saturday when the Scarlet Knights host Michigan State, earns $1.25 million in guaranteed school pay after drawing a $200,000 raise for this season in September 2014 .
Scroll through the photo gallery above to see where Flood's salary ranks in comparison to his Big Ten coaching peers.
PLUS: Is Rutgers' coach Kyle Flood the most underpaid coach in college football?
Per the terms of a contract that runs through the 2018 season, Flood is set to earn a total of $1.35 million in '16, $1.45 million in '17, and $1.55 million in '18.
With another $10,000 in guaranteed pay as a result of outside athletically-related income, Flood's total $1.26 million salary ranks 67th nationally among FBS schools. That figure ranks the Scarlet Knights fourth-year coach next-to-last among coaches in Power Five conferences, behind Kansas' David Beaty.
Flood, who has led Rutgers to bowl appearances in his first three seasons, had the distinction of owning the fifth-best career winning percentage (23-16 record, .590) among Big Ten coaches behind Ohio State's Urban Meyer (.845), Michigan's Jim Harbaugh (.682), Michigan State's Mark Dantonio (.660) and Penn State's James Franklin (.596) heading into the 2015 season.
